content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays a large, complex tissue section. The left and bottom portions consist of a densely cellular, basophilic, and infiltrative mass, characteristic of a large primary tumor. The tumor appears to be invading through multiple tissue layers. The right portion is predominantly adipose tissue. There are a few small, indistinct nodular structures within the adipose tissue that could represent lymph nodes, but the most striking feature is the extensive primary tumor. The overall impression is of a locally advanced colorectal carcinoma.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into the central part of the main tumor mass. At low magnification, this area shows a complex pattern with a mix of basophilic cellular components and pale, amorphous-looking eosinophilic areas. This appearance is suspicious for a specific tumor subtype, possibly with extracellular mucin production. Therefore, I need to magnify this area to characterize the tumor's architecture and cytology, and specifically to confirm the presence and extent of mucin, which is an important prognostic feature in colorectal cancer. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see nests and irregular glands of malignant epithelial cells floating in abundant pools of pale, acellular extracellular mucin. The tumor cells exhibit malignant features, including nuclear pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, and irregular nuclear contours. The surrounding stroma shows a desmoplastic reaction. My impression is an invasive adenocarcinoma with prominent mucinous features. If more than 50% of the tumor consists of this mucinous component, it would be classified as a mucinous adenocarcinoma.
